subject: Add replicate by volume-type to SolidFire driver
commit_message:
Add replicate by volume-type to SolidFire driver

This patch adds the needed methods to configure volume
replication based on volume-type on create, clone and
create from snapshot.

This adds methods to create volumes on a remote cluster
based on cluster_pairs info, creates the remote volumes
and enables pairing/replication between the "remote" and
the primary.

Additionally we also make sure we delete both the source
and dest on delete calls.

Finally, implement the get_replication_updates call.

To enable, the only required setting is replication_enabled.

subject: Implement V2 replication capability in SolidFire
commit_message:
Implement V2 replication capability in SolidFire

This change implements the Cinder V2 replication feature
in the SolidFire driver.

NOTE: This feature is still experimental, and is not intended
for production use during the L release for any driver including
SolidFire.  The primary purpose is to provide an experimental
implementation that can be tested and used as a reference.

To enable this feature:
The SolidFire driver currently only supports replicating to
managed backends.  In other words, another SolidFire cluster
that's configured in your OpenStack deployment (this can be
using either multi-backend, or seperate hosts).

The necessary config look like this:

enabled_backends = sf1,sf2

[sf1]
san_password = admin
san_login = admin
san_ip = 11.0.0.2
volume_driver = cinder.volume.drivers.solidfire.SolidFireDriver
volume_backend_name = sf1
secondary_backend = devbox@sf2#sf2
replication_devices = {'mvip'='11.0.0.9' 'login'='admin'\
                       'passwd'='admin'}

[sf2]
san_password = admin
san_login = admin
san_ip = 11.0.0.9
volume_driver = cinder.volume.drivers.solidfire.SolidFireDriver
volume_backend_name = sf2

This sets up cluster replication between sf1 and sf2, with sf1 being the
primary until a failover command is issued, at which time the host and
provider info entries for the failed over volume are updated and pointed
to the secondary cluster.

Running failover again, will swap the cinder primary back to the
original cluster again.

subject: Implement ability to pass CA bundle certificate for vCenter server
commit_message:
Implement ability to pass CA bundle certificate for vCenter server

Glance with vsphere backend by default verifies vCenter server TLS/SSL
certificate using system truststore (e.g.
/etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt). Here is a problem with connection
to vCenter: if we consider case with default installation, then vCenter
starts with self-signed certificate which cannot be verified using linux
shipped CA bundle. Glance starts, but fails to do any useful work,
because it generates SSL errors due to inability to verify vCenter
TLS/SSL certificate.

User can provide its own CA bundle file for Glance to verify connection,
but currently puppet-glance does not support this. This patch aims to
fix this problem, it:
- introduces new optional parameter $vcenter_ca_file which undef by
  default, which means that value will not be written to glance-api.conf
- it switches default value of vmware_api_insecure to True
- provides rspec tests for changed behaviour

commit_message:
Use physical host interfaces to connect virtual and baremetal networks

* Two new attributes in the Libvirt driver for L2NetworkDevice:

  - vlan_ifaces = []
    If Libvirt network create a bridge with name virbr1, then some tagged
    interfaces will be created on this bridge: virbr1.100, virbr1.101, ...

    Example: vlan_ifaces = [100, 101, 102]
    $ cat /etc/network/interfaces
    ...
    auto virbr1.100
    iface virbr1.100 inet manual
       vlan_raw_device virbr1
    auto virbr1.101
    iface virbr1.101 inet manual
       vlan_raw_device virbr1
    auto virbr1.102

  - parent_iface = {phys_dev=None, l2_net_dev=None, tag=None}
    Should be specified only one device: 'phys_dev' or 'l2_net_dev'.

    If Libvirt network create a bridge with name virbr3, then a parent
    interface can be added to the bridge when the network starts:

    Example: parent_iface = {phys_dev='eth5', l2_net_dev=None, tag=None}
    $ brctl addif virbr3 eth5

    Example: parent_iface = {phys_dev=None, l2_net_dev='admin', tag=100}
    $ brctl addif virbr3 virbr1.100    # 'admin' network created virbr1

subject: Allow chainloading of Inspector ramdisk over UEFI
commit_message:
Allow chainloading of Inspector ramdisk over UEFI

To send the Inspector ramdisk over HTTP rather than TFTP, we must first
send an iPXE boot image that knows how to speak HTTP, and then instruct
it to "chainload" the inspector ramdisk. Previously, we could only do
this if the machine being introspected had BIOS firmware. However, most
modern servers now use UEFI firmware, which requires a different iPXE
boot image (as described at http://ipxe.org/howto/chainloading).

We must specify the initrd in the iPXE `kernel` line to avoid the
problem described at http://forum.ipxe.org/showthread.php?tid=7589.

We include the iPXE binary images directly in the files/ subdirectory
and serve them from the puppet master. This is because

 - while there is a Debian package that contains both images, there is
   currently no package for Red Hat systems that contains the UEFI
   image;
 - downloading the images from ipxe.org would make our users vulnerable
   to any attack affecting that site.

Change-Id: I1f08578d4005c33feed84d4783a7a7693d13920c

subject: Add fullstack cross-process port/ip address fixtures
commit_message:
Add fullstack cross-process port/ip address fixtures

We've had a series of bugs with resources that need
to be unique on the system across test runner
processes. Ports are used by neutron-server and the
OVS agent when run in native openflow mode. The function
that generates ports looks up random unused ports and
starts the service. However, it is raceful: By the time the
port is found to be unused and the service is started,
another test runner can pick the same random port.
With close to 65536 ports to choose from, the chance
for collision is low, but given enough test runs, it's
happened a non-trivial amount of times, and given that
a voting job needs a very low false-negative rate, we
need a more robust solution. The same applies to IP
addresses that are used by the OVS agent in tunneling
mode, and for the LB agent in all modes. With IP addresses,
we don't check if the IP address is used, we simply
pick a random address from a large pool, and again
we've seen a non-trivial amount of test failures.

The bugs referenced below had simple, short term solutions
applied but the bugs remain remain. This patch is a correct,
long term solution that doesn't rely on chance.

This patch adds a resource allocator that uses the disk
to persist allocations. Access to the disk is guarded
via a file lock. IP address, networks and ports fixtures
use an allocator internally.

Closes-Bug: #1551288
Closes-Bug: #1561248

                    that are supposed to be assigned to the interface.

Using timeout instead of wait_for should fix this, as it's intended for
blocking calls.

subject: WIP:make sure conf is loaded first than "@periodics.periodic()"
commit_message:
WIP:make sure conf is loaded first than "@periodics.periodic()"

Current, config.parse_args is called from our common/service.py
to load ironic.conf. However, service.py imports modules in below
sequence:

ironic.api.app -> ironic.api.hooks ->
ironic.conductor.rpcapi -> ironic.conductor.manager

So for such "@periodics.periodic(spacing=CONF.xxx)" code, it runs
before ironic.conf is loaded, that is the root cause these periodic
tasks always run with default spacing values even in case which are
overwritten with special values.

In this patch, we move config.parse_args to cmd/__init__.py, to make
sure the ironic.conf will be loaded first than other python modules
which are in the import list. Then, these
"@periodics.periodic(spacing=CONF.xxx)" codes run after the conf is
loaded, so these periodic spacing in conf will effect.

Now, this is a proposed draft fix for this issue, because I encountered
new issue with this solution, ironic-api and ironic-conductor works,
but only the ironic-dbsync command is not working, will raise
ArgsAlreadyParsedError exception, because it will run CONF.register_cli_opt
after 'config.parse_args' is called. So, just commits this patch here
for reviewing and getting more good ideas to fix this 'old' issue.

Change-Id: I545d4b40889ba66c3904f0f4a6f10e1a9532582a
Closes-Bug: #1562258
